articles.title: December 1981
articles.summary: This document, the December 1981 bulletin for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), details a series of events for December 1981 and January 1982. Activities include general meetings featuring speakers on topics like the Kuiper Astrophysical Observatory and a USSR tour including a solar eclipse, various indoor and outdoor star parties, a Space Telescope tour, and board meetings. It also provides membership rates and contact information for the association's president and bulletin editors.

articles.title: FINAL REPORT
articles.summary: This final report details the results of an Oct. 19 grazing occultation observed at Los Banos, California. Nine observers successfully recorded 45 timings, which were plotted to reveal the lunar profile during the event. The observed profile showed significant deviations from the predicted path, with the moon passing approximately 0.3 miles north of its expected position and displaying unpredicted features like secondary peaks and deep valleys.

articles.title: PRELIMINARY REPORT -- NOVEMBER 15
articles.summary: Despite an official cancellation due to rain forecasts, a small group of observers proceeded with the November 15 graze expedition at Greenfield. Against all odds, they encountered partly clear skies and successfully obtained several timings before low clouds closed in. Preliminary analysis indicates a northward shift of approximately half a mile for the graze event.

articles.title: BEING SAFE FROM THE LUNATICS WHILE OBSERVING
articles.summary: This article addresses personal safety concerns for amateur astronomers observing in remote areas, drawing on the author's experiences in the Santa Cruz Mountains. It emphasizes the importance of polite interactions with strangers, choosing moderately trafficked observing sites, and presenting a confident demeanor. Key advice includes initiating friendly conversation, knowing emergency contacts, and informing someone of your observing plans.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article, updated in November 1981, details recent comet activities, including an unconfirmed sighting by Peter Stattmayer near M 33 and a confirmed sun-grazing comet observed by the P78-1 satellite in 1979, the first instance of a comet striking the sun. It also recounts the historical Great Comet of 1882, a member of the Kreutz Sungrazing Family, highlighting its close solar pass and photographic significance. The delay in reporting the 1979 event was due to the satellite's classified mission.

articles.title: Hot gases surrounding Saturn detected by Voyager:
articles.summary: Voyager 2 data has revealed a region of incredibly hot plasma surrounding Saturn, with temperatures ranging from 600 million to 1 billion degrees Fahrenheit. These gases are the hottest ever observed in the solar system, maintaining a density of approximately 30 particles per cubic foot.

articles.title: Deputy Director named for Space Telescope:
articles.summary: Dr. John M. Teem, an astronomer previously at Kitt Peak National Observatory, has been appointed Deputy Director of the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore. He had been an astronomer at Kitt Peak since 1970.

articles.title: NASA resignation:
articles.summary: Dr. Anthony J. Calio, NASA's Associate Administrator for the Office of Space and Terrestrial Applications, is expected to resign soon. He will transition to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) as its Deputy Administrator. Calio previously served as Acting Deputy NASA Administrator earlier this year.
keywords: Office of Space and Terrestrial Applications

articles.title: ESA concern:
articles.summary: The European Space Agency (ESA) is worried about potential budget cuts forcing NASA to close its Deep Space Network (DSN), which ESA had planned to use for its International Solar Polar Mission (ISPM) and as a backup for the Giotto mission. This closure would further strain relations between NASA and ESA, already tense due to NASA's earlier decision to cancel its own ISPM spacecraft.

articles.title: Indian spacecraft to be launched by U.S.S.R.:
articles.summary: India's Bhaskar 2, an earth resources satellite developed by the Indian Space Research Organization, has been shipped to the Soviet Union for an upcoming launch. The imaging spacecraft, designed for a one-year operational lifetime, was scheduled to be launched by the Soviet Union in the third week of November.

articles.title: Soviet space station:
articles.summary: The Salyut 6 space station, currently docked with Cosmos 1267, continues to provide crucial engineering data on module addition and operational capability as it enters its fifth year in orbit. The Soviet Union is reconsidering its initial plan not to reuse Salyut 6 for manned flights, with a potential use for the 1982 Soviet-French mission, though Salyut 7 remains an alternative.

articles.title: Space-based ion thrust unit scheduled for testing:
articles.summary: A Mercury Ion Thruster, built by Hughes Space and Communications for NASA and known as the Ion Auxiliary Propulsion System (IAPS), is scheduled for launch in May 1983. It will fly on the Air Force Space Test Program's P80-1 spacecraft to test its capabilities as a station-keeping device, generating 1.12 millipounds of thrust from an 8-centimeter beam.

articles.title: THE CELESTIAL TOURIST SPEAKS
articles.summary: The 'Celestial Tourist' provides a one-year review of a modified Celestron 14 telescope, detailing user-made improvements for vibration reduction and dew prevention. The author recounts a significant issue with the original optics, specifically astigmatism, which was successfully resolved by Celestron's excellent warranty service with new, high-quality optics. The article concludes with recent observing reports focusing on galaxy clusters and a planetary nebula in the Fornax constellation.

articles.title: Celestial Tourist
articles.summary: This article, a continuation of "Celestial Tourist," offers observing recommendations for deep-sky objects. It highlights a Messier-quality planetary nebula visible with 11x80 binoculars and discusses several spectacular double stars in Orion, including the challenging Rigel. The author notes that an eight-inch Dobson telescope is effective for observing these objects.

articles.title: LETTERS TO THE EDITORS
articles.summary: The 'Letters to the Editors' section includes Jay Freeman correcting a past typographical error and noting new light trailer frames at Sears suitable for transporting Dobsonian telescopes. Dick Barrett contributes to a financial debate, suggesting that long-term investment gains might be offset by inflation, potentially favoring an immediate telescope purchase. The section also features a cartoon about observing sites and a thank-you note for a talk on the Space Telescope.

articles.title: IMPRESSIONS OF THE STS-2 LAUNCH
articles.summary: The author provides a vivid first-person account of witnessing the STS-2 Space Shuttle Columbia launch, detailing his evolving perceptions of the rocket's immense scale and the anticipation surrounding the delayed event. He describes the powerful visual and auditory spectacle of the liftoff from 3.4 miles away, from a silent ascent to a body-vibrating shockwave. The experience left him with a profound sense of awe and historical significance, comparing it to future milestones in space exploration.
